Hey, just thought I'd give you a heads up that latex gloves aren't fully impermeable. When handling dangerous chemicals, it's not a bad idea to double glove and tuck your lab coat's sleeves into the gloves. Also, you probably already do this, but make sure you're using the the right gloves (generally specified on the msds) or they may not be enough to protect you.

Cool video! I like the part about the importance of wearing gloves. I recently spilled about 0.5mL of Bromine on my left hand when NOT wearing gloves. I felt an immediate burning sensation - I believe because of the exothermic reaction between the Bromine and the top layer of my skin. Thank God, I had a washbottle of water right there and washed my hand off in less than 3 seconds. At first one finger looked horrible - the Br2 bleached the skin on that finger a pale yellow. I immediately put my finger under running cool water and rubbed it to remove as much of the remaining bromine as possible. There was no further pain and the finger felt normal. The skin took on a more normal appearance after thorough washing. About a half hour later, the skin began to turn grey-brown. I put my finger in a solution of sodium thiosulfate for a few minutes and then repeated the washing, this time scrubbing with soap. Most of the discoloration went away and it seems like my finger is normal - quite scary though!

Excellent video as always, many thanks for your continued uploads. 
In terms of suggestions for further videos, I wonder if you would consider demonstrating the reaction commonly known as the barking dog: the reaction between carbon disulfide and nitrous oxide in a cylindrical vessel open at one end. Following on from this particular idea, perhaps you could post a video of the production of either of these reactants. My brief research on the subject of carbon disulfide was enough to dissuade me from attempting its synthesis, but perhaps it would be within the abilities a more learned and experienced chemist. I hope these suggestions have been helpful, and I thank you again for inspiring a fellow chemistry fanatic.
